title: Rapidly going down and no positive outlook
pros: There are no positives for working for waters
cons:
Leadership is a joke 
Strategy is wake up, think of an idea and roll with it
No evidence gathered or checked 
We are employed as drowning rats to bully junior employees & not provide any direction
Diversity is non existent. It’s a Caucasian driven and led business. Although the new CEO makes a difference. It’s a KPI they can report to the shareholders. Nothing more.
I have lost so many colleagues... dropping like flies in the company.
HR ( human remains) what a joke!! They will side with management - make no mistake of this.
Long serving employees stopped asking questions, why fight - just join. No spirit, no questions asked.
Just madness to make the same mistakes over again... let’s launch products & promote services that customers do not want & need.

New potential employees, be aware, check with former employees before coming to the interview & waste time. This is not a company that cares about mental health & well - being.

It’s a modern day minimum wage factory

Incompetent & self serving individuals keep rising to the top. Toxic managers support other toxic managers. It’s a company I do not recognise anymore. 

Waters is so far behind in internal & external concepts it will never catch up...

title: Easy job, rubbish culture
pros: Nice building, most people are friendly, onsite canteen is ok, good health/dental benefits. Good pay for amount of work required.
cons:
Huge disparity in working culture between “upstairs and downstairs” Diversity is very poor and if your personality isn’t aggressive/pushy you won’t get on. 
Old fashioned management styles, managers only interested in themselves, never take time to say thanks for hard work etc, often don’t even bother to say good morning. 
Keep employees in the dark about most things, communication very poor, lots of finding out information second or third hand rather than direct. 
Lack of interest/guidance in personal development so high staff turnover. Generally low engagement and motivation in NPO and nothing being done to improve this. Keep making pointless new rules and attitude is very much “if you don’t like it leave, you can be replaced”. Small or no bonuses, very hush hush about bonuses and pay. Little opportunity for developing/progressing within department.

title: It will never get better - get out now
pros: Some colleagues, company card & the phone
cons:
Waters now has a diversity program, what a joke. Isn’t this something that should be done from the start?? Do you implement a program to recruit men or women!! 
I have moved around so many times, I am waiting to go back where I started.
Managers will vary from department to department, ask existing & former employees- do your homework.
They are very good at rolling the red carpet at the beginning...
Some senior managers are cowards with no backbone
Check the job spec & verify all tasks in the job spec. They will over sell the role to make it look more than it is
Honestly, take another job else where, redundancies & furlough
Check reviews from the past year, the culture has become one of fear & back stabbing. Fear lead management
Don’t believe what you read about the company being innovative - it’s a joke
The company is run with VPs getting to the top on self promotion 
Really take this as a warning - do not join
People in the company are leaving for a reason... turnover is at an all time high

title: So - so company

cons: MNC with SME mindset. Mid-level managers are basically just going with the flow waiting to retire without much input.

title: Lying, two-faced robbers & managers
pros: Not working for them & home time
cons:
No leadership
Promises mean nothing, even if you have this in writing 
Toxic and corrupted leadership
Products are not innovative 
Focus on point scoring within the business instead of being customer driven 
Management do not care - they will take the frustrations out on the employees
Redundancies, moving people around, furlough, pay cuts - modern day robbers
Waters is a company that does not like to give their employees (and customers) no choice
Arrogant & complacent bunch of people you will ever come across 
The VP is so toxic, how to work your way up & tick so many employees in a very short space of time
It’s like something out of the 1940s - not modern or dynamic at all
No CRM, no new technology ... this is the way we always do things - why change!!
Sick sick sick - the worst company I have ever worked for - actively looking for work
Managers will pat each other on the back - never once with self reflection. 
Nobody leaves this place, seriously, people stay until retirement .... 
really really read this before you think about joining Waters 
They will be sweetness & light during the honeymoon phase - after that - it’s gone!

Do not think they have a good reputation, it’s not the competitors doing the damage - it’s Waters senior managers.... 

Only the favourites get promoted & certain people can walk around with impunity & no consequences. This gives them the courage & confidence to do what they want.... 

Most employees are fighting the fire & keeping their head down. Don’t be fooled by the number of vacancies... it’s not because of organic growth btw. Either people have left, been fired or just removed from the business. If you don’t play to the tune of the managers, life will be very difficult for you. All the managers are correct all the time! No one else has an opinion ....

Toxic cheap skate dump.......

Waters does not value the health & safety of their employees - it’s a modern day sweat shop.

I rate Waters 1 as I can’t go any lower

title: Great company but zero possibility to personally grow and develop.
pros: Very innovative company with a great atmosphere between colleagues. For field based staff decent company cars, food allowance and good equipment like new laptops, phones and tools.
cons:
There is zero possibility to grow. Asked for several years to move positions but in the smaller countries that is impossible. They do not listen to the employees at all in that sense and provide many BSc level jobs to people with 11 years university and Ph.D degrees. They get intellectually bored, but company is doing nothing to retain them. Also now and then they lay-off some people, which is quite American but for Europeans of course very shocking.
Also the amount of vacation days is not much for Europe 25 + 3, there is no compensation for e.g. traveling in the weekend, sometimes it is difficult to keep up a good work-life balance.

title: Depends on Location
pros:
Good Pay
Health Insurance ($100 - $240/month, good coverage)
Guaranteed Hours
Other benefits (adoption assistance, paid maternity leave, tuition reimbursement, etc)
cons: Sheetz policy makes it near impossible to fire even the worst employees. Personally I would rather have those worker protections and have them abused by a few crappy people than to not have those protections at all for the rest of us, but it does suck to walk in and realize you're working with That Coworker (or see them on the schedule and think, oh joy, so she's going to call out and we'll be understaffed again!). Any location can have bad employees, but Sheetz just makes it really hard to fire them so they stick around. But if you're a good worker, it is nice to know you have that job protection and can't just be fired for no reason.

title: It's Not What it Used To Be, But it's Still a Step Above the Rest
pros: Competitive Pay at most levels, Better Than Average Medical/Health Benefits, 401k matching (up to limit), ESOP
cons: Raises for non-salaried management positions are not performance-based and have a cutoff after a specific tenure mark is reached. Work can be monotonous especially if you do not have a solid team around you to support each other. The burnout period can be quick based on store environment. If you're a kid that is in high school or college it will pay the bills. If you have aspirations to move up the ladder, you can make decent money. If you find yourself in a career rut, stuck between those two pillars it is going to be a tough pill to swallow.

title: Absolutely no work/life balance
pros: Advancement opportunities, benefits, bonuses, leadership, management, family ran
cons: Stressful, no work/life balance, unrealistic goals/expectations/ working major holidays

title: Amazing company
pros: I love working at Sheetz! The management is amazing, and it pays fairly decently. They also reward you more, the longer you stick with them. For instance, I just got an $800 bonus on Dec. 11 ON TOP OF MY PAYCHECK after only working for them for a year.
cons: Not really any. They could use slightly better policies when it comes to call offs with poor weather conditions and stuff but other than that, as long as you do as you are told and don't back talk the managers it's a great place to work!

title: Fast Food Workers Make More Money
pros: Possible health care coverage IF you meet full time status. 50% off MTO food when working.
cons: Extremely low pay for job duties and demands. Treatment of staff is biased and obvious. At times, staff is spoken to worse than animals by management and corporate is not helpful when you look for support. Work schedule is all over the place and you get calls or texts every single day asking to pick up shifts but it’s never on your schedule

title: It had its pros and cons.
pros:
They pay is good, was better than when I worked at GetGo when they paid $9/hr.
The company trains you at a different location until you are comfortable with starting at the location you applied for.
cons: The management at this location in Robinson Township wasn’t the best. When I started, the general manager had just taken over the store and didn’t have any of the other employees in line. They did whatever they pleased and pushed some work off to the newer guys to “teach them”.

title: Good people, satisfying work, interpersonal drama
pros:
-Work is fast-paced and satisfying
-Teaches problem-solving skills, good customer service and interpersonal skills, and how to multi-task quickly and effectively
-Fantastic benefits
-Good program for internal training and promotion
cons: -Lots of unprofessional interpersonal drama, particularly among management staff

title: Quality of experience is dependent on location
pros: Benefits (health, dental, vision, 401K, stocks, etc.)
cons: Management hassled employees at my location into not taking any breaks (as it is you're only permitted a single 20 minute break on the clock). So basically you would work a 8-9 hour shift with either a 5 minute break or no break at all, and they'd give you some coupons for a couple of hot dogs as payment.

title: Could be a little better

title: They really try to make Sheetz seem like a great family-owned co. to work for & I had a much different experience!

I guess great health benefits...i would not know bc they hire you as a FT employee then they cut hours on the schedule & you are now a PT employee & do not qualify for health benefits. 
Store manager was kind ect...
cons: No loyalty for employees. They ask you what days you are available during interview & say “Schedule/availability is wide open” & then cut hours & try to force employees to work days/hours they cannot & were upfront about from beginning.  “Point System” is insane!! Felt like I was back in elementary school again. Unrealistic expectations (esp. w/the work environment that they create) & you get scolded when you have enough points to get fired (these points are easily acquired), however, they do not actually fire you until business is slow & they need to eliminate employees anyway ect... SHEETZ’S TURNOVER RATE IS INSANE I AM SURE!

title: Great Company to Work For
pros: Great compensation. Quarterly Bonuses based on customer survey scores, profit margins, etc. Higher positions get higher bonuses. A lot of room to move up/advance career. Almost always has overtime available. Culture in most stores feels like a 2nd family.
cons: Lack of Training due to a multitude of reasons. Very trial by fire which can result in unnecessary write ups. Retail Job. Overtime usually due to turnover/call-outs.

title: Great for people with disabilities
pros: Patient and understanding with disabilities, gave me a calm, supportive environment with extra time to learn, encouraging and positive management, Sheetz coworkers feel like family, hard work feels rewarded, lots of room to move up and make a career of Sheetz
cons: Don't always get 30 scheduled hours to keep health benefits when business is slow in the summer, have gotten letters about losing benefits, lack of work-life balance and stress affected mental health and performance at times

title: It was an ok job
pros: The pay, bonuses, and benefits were all great. It was plenty of opportunities to move up and branch out in the company. The training program was pretty awesome as well, plus you get trips, dinners, incentives and more.
cons: The actual job is awful. The turn over rate is terrible. They don’t give stores enough employees and hours when it’s busy and cut hours when it’s slow. You have to work every single holiday and don’t receive enough vacation or personal time off. The point system also sucks, and they take too long to get rid of bad lazy workers.

title: Overall okay
pros: Pay was decent. Job promotions were available to those who wanted it. Bonuses and coupons for good work.
cons: I was either scheduled 2 weeks in a row without a day off or I barely got 20 hours a week. They always wanted you to stay and work double or triple shifts if the weather was nasty. So, they had no concept of employees having family responsibilities.

title: A company that cares.

cons: Structure store manager schedule. Wish they were more flexible.

title: Good until new management
pros: Great place IF you have a manager who actually wants to work at the location they are at .
cons: Manager can get away with favoritism. Letting an employee work 90 something hours while having an employee for 4-8 and lose healthcare benefits is not right . Saying the employee doesn’t get hours because you can communicate with her because she has an accent is discriminatory behavior .

title: We’re not going anywhere
pros: Come hell or high weather P.C. Richard & Sons isn’t going anywhere. A company like this doesn’t survive for decades on end to simply give in when it faces a rough patch. I’m speaking primarily of the pandemic of course just in case you haven’t figured it out. The resilience of this company, its management, its customers and its employees are a true testament to how much people believe in this brand.
cons: Considering how this year has been going, let’s just say some cons are very much forgivable. Gotta keep the bottom line afloat anyway we can.

title: Many opportunities to excel
pros: One of those jobs where opportunities to succeed are numerous, but only if you’re willing to reach out and take them yourself. As long as you’re active and interacting with customers in some form or fashion you’ll do just fine. Gregg Richard has been doing a phenomenal job keeping things together during the COVID outbreak. Couldn’t ask for a better job.

title: A Place to Work the Rest of Your Life
pros:
A career for a lifetime! 

I started working for P.C. Richard & Son, in 1989 as a sales counselor in Riverhead, NY. From there, I became a car audio manager, a store manager, assistant manager, district manager, warehouse manager, operations manager, and then finally as the Director of Service, where I am today.  How?  Why?  Hard work pays off! If you are patient, show the company what you have to offer and believe in what the company stands for, you will have a job for life!
cons: There are none! Remember, be patient and work hard. Get noticed for the right reasons.

title: Family friendly company that cares
pros: P.C. Richard & Son is a company that  has been family owned for over 110 years. The original philosophy of the founder A.J. Richard continues today. Take care of your customers, employees, and vendors like they were your own family.
cons: If you just want to show up for a work day and not make a difference then this is not the job for you.

title: Terrible Place to Work. Horrible Pay Structure. Toxic Environment.
pros: Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, Easter. 401k
cons: In-house training model is vastly different from what is used in store. Store managers value quick sales at the cost of ensuring that the item is a good fit for the customer and risk high returns as a result, while at the same time punishing salesmen for the returns. The commission structure is designed so that it's rare you'll see commission, as the sales department is nearly completely commission based and though you receive a salary, the commission is used to pay your salary, so when there's no commission made, and you still receive a check, when you do make commission, it is owed to the company for when they paid you and you didn't make commission. One of my managers drank on the job, daily. Racist/sexist jokes - MANY LOCATIONS/ALL LEVELS OF EMPLOYEES.

title: Wonderful People, Maybe One or Two Not Great
pros: This environment provides an excellent space to work and think. With constant evaluations and training, you are guaranteed to continually get better at your job and satisfy customers. I should know. I won best customer service awards many times.
cons: Small company. Working it’s way up.

cons: In the store in can be very cut throat because of commission sales

title: Low commissions
pros: Once you figure out their system, it’s pretty easy. Laid back environment, for the most part. TV always on.
cons:
The commission structure for aces is totally demoralizing. Flat, 1% commission on anything you sell. At that rate, it makes more sense to “sell your sale" to an full salesman rather than write it up yourself. Or make yourself out as a delivery driver (make sure you communicate that you expect to be paid for a delivery..... EVERY TIME). 
Also, costumers are total morons and will haggle over everything.

title: Don’t apply here please!! Save yourself the trouble!
pros: My coworkers that I got trained with were fantastic, a lot of them left already which is good for them, they deserve better, but they were one of the only good things. You get to work from home too.
cons: Everything else. Borderline harassment from management while in calls. They spam you from the side lines while listening into your calls to tell you what to say and do, then it flusters you, and then tell you that you missed a few things because of the fact that they were spamming you about other stuff WHILE flustering you. It’s a horrible away to go about helping. The managers for the most part are useless, they all have the same job but make random titles to make it look different but they have the exact same title. They just sit in your calls and listen to you and then say they’ll support you cause they’re the manager on duty in that moment and not respond for 10-15 mins when you actually do need them, and then also give you the wrong answer after the wait. If you call in sick you owe that time back to them so you have to use one of your days off in the next few weeks to make up for that. Bathroom breaks are unpaid, I get normal breaks not being paid for and that’s fine, but the fact that they can’t pay for you to go use the bathroom is sad. You are forced into a religious charity which isn’t even a good one when you read into it, you also don’t have a choice in which one you want to do. If you can’t do the religious charity then they’ll probably fire you so save yourself the trouble if you’re atheist, especially when the donors are religious in the most insane way possible. You aren’t making a difference because you’re begging one person for money to help another, especially during COVID when the people you’re begging money from are already struggling. And this religious charity is based in the US, who didn’t get much support during COVID from the government. If you do get lucky to get money, and it’s not what THEY want, they only want monthly donations on a credit card or through your debt, then thats unfortunate. You got a one time gift of 100 dollars? That’s rough, should have been monthly donations. Even if you broke it down and they paid 100 dollars in the course of the 12 months that’s still better than the 100 dollars one time. I was told that I need to hit a certain % of monthly donations a week in order to be “safe.” Any good reviews has to be written by management because they’re completely not true. If you have any morals or care about people in any way, this isn’t the job for you. I got in trouble more than enough times because I wasn’t making my “second ask” which is when they say no ask again, and then when they say no to the second, ask again. You have to ask 3 times and instead of helping build relationships with these people, you’re tearing them down from ever wanting to support again by constantly pressuring them when they’re not financially able too. That’s why again if you have morals, don’t do this job please! Also if you value your computer in any way, don’t work here because they make you download a ton of programs that slow it down drastically, even with the best gaming PC out there.

title: Porch = A Solid Career Choice
pros:
* The company adapted well to remote work after the COVID19 crisis began
* Flexible with hours. Just get your work done and there aren't any issues.
* Teams are solid. There are a number of highly skilled people at Porch.
* Compensation is entirely dependent on the value you bring. You might have to push to get what you think you deserve, and they will listen.
* People say the environment at Porch is toxic. The same can be said for so many tech companies. With this line of work comes a high level of responsibility and acuity. You want to make it - you distinguish yourself.
cons: * Sometimes there is too much work to go around and excessive pressure will be placed on teams / individuals to get it done in effort to achieve milestones. Again, it is up to you to strike a balance between work/life in effort to make yourself a valued asset.

title: No Perks, No Ethos.
pros:
- Porch has an uncanny ability to attract quality talent, and in turn, the people I worked with were kind, talented and driven.
- As a nebulous organization without a distinct product, the opportunities to tackle unique challenges are abundant.
- Most roles enjoy a degree of autonomy.
cons:
- As previously stated, Porch doesn't have a distinct product. M&A (i.e. buying income) keeps Porch afloat.
- People are not valued. A round of layoffs in Q1 left the org at the "right size," until COVID-19 led to company-wide furloughs. With the partial furlough employees working twice as hard at half the pay, the full-furlough employees were no longer needed. Interesting.
- There is a distinct drop-off in communication between C level and VP level. Leadership comes off as stilted and tone deaf.
- Below market salary levels and major discrepancies in pay levels for employees with the same roles.
- Porch laid off US based sales team in lieu of Mexico/Costa Rica based reps.

title: GREAT SMART PEOPLE
pros: Porch deeply cares about its employees and Career growth opportunities are plentiful if you take advantage of all the resources at hand. Porch wants its employees to be invested in their work and to feel connected to its larger mission, even as we constantly evolve the path towards that mission. Growth can be accelerated in any given role if you choose to improve anything, as there is plenty low hanging fruit for you to go after.
cons: Porch's culture is demanding and fast paced. The greatest aspect of working at Porch is that everyone is very ambitious and very smart. The problem with this is that they all expect the very same of you. Holding a very high bar for excellence can certainly be demanding so it's important to make sure you're always carefully paying attention to your own personal work/life balance.

title: Fast Paced With Great Growth Opportunities
pros:
- Smart co-workers who are great people to work with
- A problem space that allows us to dramatically transform the homeownership experience
- Infinite opportunities to grow your career
- Consistent growth of the business
cons:
- The company moves quickly - if the status quo is what you like, it's probably not the right place for you.
- The company vision is ambitious and staffing means that we make some progress against a lot of initiatives vs a lot of progress on fewer initiatives. The ambitious vision can be challenging for some.
- You have to love solving problems - they'll come up everyday and the problems are hard.
- COVID impacted the business and resulted in a furlough and some attrition.

title: Seattle engineering is a ghost town
pros: Honestly, there really are none.
cons:
Just look at the other one-star reviews.

Every way and everywhere you look at Porch there are rampant issues. The software engineering organization has been losing senior engineers, key leaders and managers at a continually increasing pace. I'm no longer confident that Porch has enough of the right people to even meet their goals. Not that they ever could. The dizzying pace of pivoting and chasing new money makers, has created a product and engineering organization that is overworked and spread ridiculously thin. The majority of the remaining key engineering talent is bogged down supporting dozens of services, product lines and business asks. 

Porch lacks the money and focus to keep strong people at the company. The furlough, toxic salary plans and layoffs are just symptoms of a senior leadership team that had every opportunity to succeed and squandered it at every chance. Instead, they have transformed an organization filled with innovation and optimism into a spam call agency that obsessive crosses the line of ethical business practices.

title: Great place for outspoken folks - struggles with employee recognition
pros: Lots of opportunity for growth
cons: Company struggles with proactively valuing to long-time employees

title: Very poor Lead Support
pros: Great support from other customer service reps.
cons: No support for upset customers, the lead will put off the customer complaint until they become extremely upset and keep calling.

title: Labor hand
pros: Laid back felt welcome.as the new guy
cons: Way to laid-back mixing papers up.  Pay checks

title: Salary
pros: Good growth and great benefits
cons: Still up and coming reputation

title: 3 Financial controllers and 3 heads of legal in less than 12 months
pros: Beyond their leaders, most people are nice
cons:
The entire finance organization has quit and been replaced due to shady practices and pressure from management to bend the rules, they have been through 3 VPs of legal in the past year. If that doesn't scare you, you are not paying attention.

They took a $5MM+ PPP loan to fund a money pit of a losing business model due to the CEO's connection with bankers.

title: Rode hard, put up wet
pros: The idea of how they help homeowners is a noble cause.
cons: Senior managers are unlicensed, no experience selling. Cold, fake, suspicious, vindictive.

title: This place is bad
pros: None the place is horrible
cons: Pay is deceiving and management is awful

title: Disappointing
pros: My coworkers were the best part, hands down.
cons: To put it simply, I invested my heart and soul into the company, and after two years got let go during a round of layoffs. Porch cuts the good ones and keeps the bad ones. Shady business practices pushed by upper management that really messed with my moral compass as a young professional on a daily basis.

title: Mixed bag of good and bad
pros:
- Management does try to create a positive, inclusive atmosphere and are mostly successful.
- Freedom to propose and implement solutions with minimal pushback. 
- Autonomy is high.
cons:
- Huge disconnects between teams and poor communication
- Project completion and delivery is often a battle. The testing / release process is a mess.

title: Not the dream they sold me when hired.
pros:
-Laid back atmosphere 
-Overall people were nice and welcoming
-Rod is awesome
cons:
-You're lied to in training about where leads come from
-Other teams aren't held accountable for poor performance
-They're slowly outsourcing jobs to Mexico 
-The CEO offers very little direction or security of a financially sound future
-They don't hire by company values, I heard things come out of people's mouths that I could sue over
-Pay is directly connected to the success of the product, and the product doesn't work in 50% of the markets yet we take people's money knowing that 
-A LOT of money is made off of FAKE LEADS unnecessarily since they train you to sell to just about anyone as long as they aren't felons

title: Porch
pros: Great team dynamic, everyone works together
cons: Hit your numbers or you will not have a good time in the role

title: Poor product and code quality
pros:
- You will find a few genuinely good people here that are great to work with
- Good snacks
cons:
- Worst code base I have ever touched. Other reviews that mention poor quality and moving slowly are 100% accurate
- The culture is not good. People like to pretend that it is great, but there is a major ego problem and a lack of desire to change
-  Suggesting any newer ways of doing things is quickly shot down because "We have always done it this way" (An real quote I heard from multiple people in the engineering dept)
- Leadership picks favorites, felt like I was in high school again
- No place for career growth
- Poor compensation for the industry

title: Good place to work, wish they focused on one issue
pros: Smart leadership, great co-workers and company culture. Pay is fair.
cons: Company did a lot of pivoting, a lot of talented people but it seemed like too many key players were pulled in multiple directions at the same time.

title: Good coworkers, no growth
pros: Friendly, helpful co-workers.  Ok benefits.
cons: Favoritism.  Discrimination.   In the year that I have been with Porch, I have repeatly seen people with zero experience get promoted over people with many years experience.  I have witnessed this company just emotionally destroyed what used to be happy people.  They are now moving all of there small branches to Mexico and focusing solely on insurance.  When you work at a company that the only happy people are managers, that is a problem.  The leads and supervisors will tell you it is a toxic environment.  They deceive you from the minute you show up for your interview.  Telling you your pay is one thing, when in actually, your pay is $10.58 an hour.  If you are one of those lucky 1% who make the full bonus structure, you will be rewarded with a $1200 bonus check.  They will tell you it is a customer service  sales job.  What it really is, is cold calling telemarketing.  They do not care about the employees, so because of this, sick people come to work all of the time because they can not afford to miss work.  They are a revolving door because the good people leave for better work environments and better pay.  The people who stay are the ones who feel they can not find anything better, so they stay and complain with others.  The moto between the employees is another day another penny.  If you are an younger female and white, you won't reach managment for many years.  Where you have male counterparts that hired are for management fresh out of college with zero experience and female coworkers that are nonwhite get promoted.  Only excuse given is your age, recently happened to one of our leads.   Older females will never get a promotion.  They prefer the younger crowd.  This past year I have witnessed one woman get turned down time after time for promotions and she has more experience than the majority of all of the floor managers combined.   My advice to anyone thinking of applying here, DON'T!  This company will suck the soul right out of you.   And if management promises you something, get it in writing!

title: What an appalling place to work
pros: If you can't get a different job
cons: A mercenary organization just trying to pump customers and contractors through it's sales funnel to keep the lights on.  It doesn't offer value to anybody.

title: Don’t work here
pros: Money is great and some of the workers are great
cons: They are shady, never consistent and don’t live to their values they preach so much

title: Unsustainable business
pros: Very little micro-managing. Most devs get a large amount of individual autonomy.
cons: Scummy business model/practices, Most of the talent has jumped ship.

title: Great Teamwork!
pros: You have great Leaders and coworkers ready to help you out.
cons: Mexico agents don't get any benefits.

title: Good job
pros: Commission, paid by hour in dollars
cons: Cold sales can be hard

title: pro-Aquisition
pros: good training. Great culture and people, 100% remote work. Decent pay.
cons: stressful, constant changes, hight turnover.

title: great part time work for student, artists, and retired
pros: short shifts over 5 days, can apply what you learn to all aspects of future jobs/ personal life
cons: high pressure, high sales demands, low pay

title: Good sales foundation
pros: Great clients to work with. Fantastic causes to support if you like the arts and non profits
cons: Can be a bit old school and resistant to change. No substantial career progression.

title: Telemarketing  Easier if  Part-Time
pros: remote, friendly team, holidays off
cons: repetitive, low pay, no benefits

title: Fundraising and subscription sales
pros: Team dynamics, LGBTQ+ friendly, opportunities for advancement or extended hours, centrally located (downtown Toronto)
cons: Call center work can be challenging or boring sometimes. People with extreme anxiety talking over the phones should not apply. Can seem tough when either an employee or a campaign as a whole is behind in it's goals.

title: good workplace to be in.
pros: Good position. thank you for everything.
cons: There is No cons that I can think of.

title: Good
pros: great people, flexible hours, worth-while campaigns
cons: minimum wage and short hours, otherwise no complaints

title: Great manager
pros: Fun working environment, lots of support
cons: Minimum wage job , long script

title: Great work environment / Bad work culture
pros: helps build good connections, alot of learning possibilities and can really help expand your work possibilities
cons: no time limits! if you are stuck with a bad faculty which is not by your choice, you are doomed!

pros:

cons:

No other cons

title: Great
pros: Diversity, Inclusiveness, Real, Clever, Open
cons: Far, distant, strict, busy, standing

title: Deputy Manager\Executive HR
pros: Environment, Staff members, coordination among the group
cons: Sometimes feeling of negligence of old employees

title: Teaching assistant
pros: Exposure to highly qualified faculty
cons: Have not faced any issue till now

title: Awesome company, bad management.
pros:
-Health care benefits
-Paid vacation/ Sick leave
-Free membership to costco including several memberships if you have a friend or family member you want to give it to
-Credit card through Citi has free annual fee so no need to pay the $135 annual fee as an employee
-Networking with great hard working people
-Pay
cons:
-Experience over education
-broken open door policy
- %80 of the year the store is under staffed until the holidays, even after that the store would not put people to work on busy days, causing the front end to still take your personnel
-Safety should be an even higher priority, I worked in major sales for 8 years with experience in other departments, the upper management will continuously bombard you with tasks over the radio when your department will be under staffed because the front end needed them, but they never understand that you need them too, so your handling 2 different members at the same time with less staff & still trying to finish the first task they asked you while still answering respectfully for each call. Sometimes I would be alone in the department and the staff would make me move big furniture alone and would never send anyone to help, but whenever they asked for our help we always went up to the front end. It took them 6 years to give the department shoulder dollys to prevent hernias only after I had bought one for my department
-Lastly professionalism

title: One of the best Retailers to work for. I have no complaints or criticisms.
pros: Amazing pay and benefits. 401K match, topped out at $23.50 after 6 years and from then on received bonuses every 6 months. After 5 years I got 2 $1,500 bonus per year; at 7 years 2 $2,000 bonuses per year; and at 10 years 2 $2,500 bonus per year. The highest was 2 $3,000 bonuses per year  at 20 years of service. The quality of work and employees is top notch. They have a generous medical and dental package. It was less than $40 for me and my child per month taken out of my paycheck. They have paid sick leave and paid vacation time which steadily increases after years of service. The call in process was quick and painless. They offered a free trip to Hazeldon and FMLA leave through the company for my struggles with Addiction. They stuck by me until I couldn't fight my addictions any longer and decided to resign. Most of my Costco friends still work there and are lifers. We remain friends to this day.
cons: It is a tough  working on your feet on concrete floors 40 hours a week. My body suffered with a lot of joint pain. But since being drug free and moving from MN to a warmer state I have no more joint pain. I would recommend boots or great tennis shoes designed to be worn outside on concrete. They have very high expectations which can make one feel under pressure if taken too seriously.

title: They won't train you properly
pros: When trained properly and explained what to do, the job wasn't bad at all. We got shifted around a lot. Assisting the cashier and doing gobacks wasn't bad. Lots of walking and running around but not bad. The Bakery Department was also backbreaking but fun to work at. Great coworkers and always busy, time passes by fast. Free food in the break room during certain holidays.
cons: They absolutely do not train you for most of the positions They quite literally throw you in there without explaining much. And then when you mess up, it's on you. Only once you mess up, you're explained how to properly do the job that was given to you. But guess what? You're going to keep messing up and looking bad because you were never fully taught what to do. It's because they don't actually care about the seasonal employees. They're bottom of the bill and expendable. God forbid you actually put in some effort to train us first.

title: Where do I begin?
pros:
•Time & 1/2 on sundays
•free executive membership after your 90 days (get 2% back in stores) 
•the benefits (which I don’t use) 
•opportunity to gain additional experience if you are willing to make it known you want to learn 
• if they like you, you can get a better schedule
cons:
• you have to be willing to work weekends and pre/post holidays (no vacation is allowed around those times) 
•a large majority of management has been in the warehouse for extended periods of time so they become VERY cliquey & have a tendency to look down on you if you’re not a favorite 
•god forbid someone who’s been with the company less than a year gets a position in optical/photo/pharmacy even if they are better fit for the work. 
•seniority is a major factor in their decision making with promotions and even the little things like who’s put on a register no matter the performance level
•last but not least, costco claims to frown upon family working together. Well I’m here to say that my warehouse in Tucson has multiple supervisor couples, supervisor & subordinate relations and so so so many other marriages/ couples & even parent/child relations happening. It makes for A very awkward work environment and causes a LOT of drama when couples feud.

title: Working at Costco
pros: Costco has been recession and COVID-19 proof.  I always have my minimum contracted hours and frequently I can get more hours if wanted. I can move around departments and help out.  I look good being a jack of all trades and I don't get bored/burned out in one area.  I work with fantastic people and it's like a family.  We have excellent benefits.  I get paid holidays and time and a half on Sundays.  They work with my schedule so I can be with my children during mandatory home school.
cons: Some of management and the supervisors can play favorites and make some employees feel unwelcome.  Costco upper management isn't always great about communication and training.  Some employees have certain knowledge and others don't and vice versa.

title: Pushy typical corporate America but nice people (non management)
pros: The pay starts nice from the beginning - it's HARD physical work, but the pay helps!  The base level employees who make the place what it is and do all the work are amazing and kind people.
cons: Hard physical work. They have you pushing carts for months and months even if you have seniority. They are weird and old fashioned about even small visible tattoos or a nose stud. The higher ups with the company are cutthroat and controlling, and it's very clear that they feel like they are alpha dog. They never give you a steady or set schedule and you aren't allowed to have another part time job, they want to own your life and have you at the ready for them at any point.

title: It's fine
pros: It's a great company if you are looking for something simple. Costco is often called the "Dream Killer", for many reasons, none of which are bad. They pay their employees well, they provide amazing benefits, and they are a fantastic work environment (for the most part). It's hard to leave Costco after you've been there for a few years because starting somewhere else, you're almost guaranteed to have to take a paycut and lose benefits.
cons: Top-out pay is only so high and the level of entitlement from the people that shop at Costco can be extremely overwhelming, and will take an incredible mental and emotional toll that can honestly be expected from any retail company. It's retail, what do you expect? My biggest problem is that the company is fraught with favoritism, but honestly, what company isn't?

title: Okay overall
pros:
The pay is decent. They pay you a fair wage instead of the minimum.
You get a free membership plus another free one for another household. You get to shop in bulk for cheap and gas.
They encourage you to tell any concerns you have with other employees, managers, customers, etc who mistreats you.
Benefits like insurance.
cons:
No actual training. They sort of just put you out there, and somehow expect you to know what to do.
It can be difficult to work with other cashiers because some make their own rules and gets passive when you don't do it their way.
Pushing carts outside can be difficult, but I guess it gives you some workout.
The employee website is so old and outdated

title: About as good as it gets for retail
pros:
The structures that Costco has in place for things like Health insurance and vacation/personal time are great by any standards, but even moreso when compared with most retail and entry-level jobs. 

Pay increases over time at specified benchmarks, and eventually you can even qualify for bonuses, no matter what position. 

Several departments, normally there is something for everybody.
cons:
Can be tough to ascend through the ranks unless you transfer due to employee retention. 

Shifts will vary every week due to needs of the warehouse.

Not all warehouses are staffed evenly, some struggle more than others.

title: Morning Stocker
pros: Good Pay while still in school and great benefits
cons: Some Front end managers and supervisors. a lot of favoritism and scheduling if it does not involve school

title: Costco Pros and Cons
pros: Costco is a great company to work for when it comes to benefits and a good hourly wage. During busier seasons you can easily pick up more hours. If you are hard-working and do whatever task or job you are put on it is not hard to be recognized for that. There are several different departments you can be trained in which will give you a more versatile experience and job opportunity.
cons: Communication from management or to management can be weak; there have been a few occasions or school classes I have had to change my work schedule for, and I directly and clearly communicated it to several of the managers and I was still scheduled for days I was unable to come into work. Many of the employees at Costco do not seem to enjoy their job...possibly being that they have been there for years.

title: Let's not get to comfortable here.
pros: Costco provides outstanding benefits and can be an incredibly positive place to work. If you're willing to work your way from the bottom to prove you have what it takes, Costco is for you!
cons: This Pandemic has laid bare the true values of corporate leadership. They seem to be less interested in the health and safety of their employees and more focused on the anti mask crowd, catering to their selfishness. All to meet sales goals.

title: Be ready to WORK for that money!
pros: Great people, excellent company to work for. If you manage to get in FT, you’re set. Stay and retire from here. They pay a fair wage, even for PT seasonal. Expect to work hard for that wage! They will work you!
cons: Very strict late/absent policies, including 1 minute from break. It takes a LONG time to go FT. Years.

title: Good, but could be GREAT if not for membership & credit card sales
pros: Great pay (time and a half every Sunday), health benefits, free executive membership, raises based on hours worked, closed on major holidays, work/life balance
cons: Seniority determines work schedule (mornings vs nights) instead of work performance. On your feet the entire shift. Advancement is determined by longevity with the company, not individual work performance.

title: Best Professional Truck Driving job in the industry!!!
pros: It’s all drop and hook or live unload by Costco forklift driver while you wait for them to finish unloading. 100% no touch freight. Very well compensated ($29.10 hr), excellent benefits, time and half on Sunday... 401K and great people at company, driver’s, management, supervisors. Great Company indeed!!!
cons: May have to work weekends for a long time, extremely early routes( 12:01 am) and if you’re not an early bird, this can be extremely dangerous if driving fatigued and your not used to driving this early shift it’s very easy to get exhausted fatigue wise... so just be careful driving and use common sense and communication with management as well.

title: Great Pay and Benefits, Low Flexibility
pros: Pay is great for an entry-level job and many people benefit greatly from health insurance. Co-workers are also some of the best workers I have met.
cons: Scheduling flexibility is very low for an entry-level job, you slowly accumulate sick-time but at the start, you cannot really miss a shift for any reason. The only shift I missed in my first 90 days was because I totaled my car. They do there best to weed out the bad workers and in the end it's a great thing, just a lot of commitment at the start.

title: Salary is not enough for giving your life away
pros: Job security and can be fun at times.
cons: There is never ever ever enough employees to be successful. managers have to be on cash registers and push carts and do things that are non managerial most every day. In fact if you actually do get to do the responsibilities your accountable for its a miracle. Decent wages at the surface but to be a manager means they own you and expect you to work whenever they need you and they could careless what is happening with your family on the outside. Plan on working 60-70 hours plus a week if you really want to get somewhere as a manager. when working that much the salary actually isn't as good as they lead you to believe.

title: I really enjoyed Costco in Bozeman, MT. As primary relief & would love that position again or part-full time staff.
pros: They really had a seamless operation & patients rarely had to wait long for their meds. The techs knew or were learning their roles & the clerks had it down perfectly.
cons: At the time I worked there, there was a real lack of communication between the manager & the staff pharmacist & what seemed to be a power struggle.

title: Great benefits
pros: Great benefits even as a part timer. Have the ability to cross train in multiple departments. Raises based on hours work and not job performance. Full timers employees who have been there for over 5+ are getting paid $ 21+ to push carts. Sundays are always time in a half.
cons: In a union building, people take advantage of the seniority card. Toxic environment when people complain and are unhappy all the time. Yet, many people have been there for years and are too comfortable.

title: Cares about customers too much
pros: They pay well, give good benefits
cons: Management is not cohesively-minded and they care about their individual customers so much that they are willing to completely change operations and tremendously increasing their employees' workloads, while creating confusion for the majority of customers (and employees), simply to please the one who anonymously complains to corporate about something petty.

title: Never would of thought
pros: None! they sell you the Costco dream and expect you to work anytime they want and with no benefits for 6 month!!!! also lie to you whrn they tell you they will work with you!
cons: no benefits for 6 month! no flexibility to work with people with families and during COVID no help at all

title: Great Company
pros: Competitive pay, reasonable hours, multiple opportunities to grow and move around the company, family like atmosphere, generous benefits, always something new every day.
cons: Members can be challenging at times (it's retail after all), training can be very lax, physically demanding.

title: The Best of the Worst
pros:
-(Some) Friendly Employees 
-Free Exec Membership (after 9 months)
-401k plan (after 9 months)
-$15/hour base pay
-2 weeks vacation pay (after 1 year)
cons:
-Useless/Rude Management 
-Difficulty Moving 
-Rude Members
-Innapropriate Coworkers
-Difficult to earn Sick Hours
-Some incredibly rude coworkers

title: Okay Get ready to wait in line.
pros: Great benefits. And employees become lifetime friends.
cons: Get ready to wait in line because you wont move up in this company if your seniority is low. Only way to move up is to work for them for an amount of years. Good luck trying to move up if you don't have the years. Its not about how hard you work or how good of a worker you are. Years matter.

title: Review on Costco Wholesale for the employment benefits
pros: Great customer care great benefits great health insurance great employees helpful people and wonderful boss
cons: Not enough pay not enough time off not enough tuition reimbursement not enough time to educate clients not enough of an initiative to sell and not enough sick time.

title: Good place to work
pros: Decent training, support, and follow-up coaching. Co-workers and bosses were mostly all wonderful. Job security and great pay and benefits.
cons: Pressure to sell, smile constantly (until your face hurts), and be sugary sweet to members even if they treat you badly or lie to your manager to get you in trouble.

title: Good work for decent pay
pros: Pay is decent for sure is livable wage specially if your single or married with 1 child
cons: Can be harsh at times with management and trying to transfer stores and they will expect you to go above and beyond with no thank you

title: Great Company
pros: Benefits and pay are unmatched, especially in this area. They really care about work/life balance and have worked with me numerous times to make sure I'm able to take care of things at home.
cons: A little micromanaging at times, though that's not usually a problem in my department. The biggest con is actually some of the members, but Costco has no problem kicking people out if they get too awful.

title: Great benefits for the responsibilities
pros: Flexible around school, and generally a good work environment. Even the non-union stores have great protection for the employees. Pay is decent, and raises are based on hours worked or additional certifications achieved. Opportunities are present to move up without a degree, as long as you're willing to put in the hours and basically live your life around your job.
cons: If your manager sucks then good luck.

title: Decent Pay for Idaho. Too much of a grind to climb
pros: Very friendly staff. great pay and benefits. This is a good job if you don't wanna bother with school or need some side cash and wanna hustle long hours.
cons: This is a job for folks who are younger and don't have much aspiration beyond $30/hr salary maybe after 7 years of hustle. If you wanna be a corporate peon, this is the job for you!

title: It’s rough- really rough
pros: Besides the benefits, the pay is decent- but you earn every cent.
cons: It’s one thing to be treated inhumanly by the general public day in and day out, but when the people you “work for” continually treat you like a door mat it makes the decent pay less appealing.

title: Problems
pros: Good benefits, great pay, flexible schedule, plenty of in house job opportunities.
cons: Management unwilling to take employee complaints seriously, managers hire friends and family so trying to report issues is extremely difficult.

title: Prevalence of Harassment, Bullying, and Favouritism.
pros: Great benefits and decent pay.
cons: Meritless pay/raises. You’ll break your back and make the same as those that try just hard enough not to get fired. There is wide-spread bullying, harassment, and favoritism. It felt like middle school. They’re lucky I left without suing them.

title: Great benefits
pros: Specifically Ft.Oglethorpe Costco! Friendly management/ nice coworkers
cons: Women in pharmacy like a highschool clique. Never once did they say hello when I clocked in at 2 every single day.

title: "Merchandiser/Stocker"
pros: The culture and work environment depends on location. Some warehouses operate much more efficiently than others. Often comes down to the level of autonomy and commitment between supervisors and employees. FT and PT employees receive great health benefits.
cons: Opportunities for career advancement are often not based on the merits of ones education or career experience. Instead, seniority and internal social connections take priority. Compensation often doesn't match the level of work invested into the company.

title: Not that good.
pros: Pay is okay but that it.
cons: The job is physically demanding. It wouldn’t be so bad if they don’t need you there at 3AM in the morning. Honestly I think that’s my number 1 issue with the job. You need to be there so early! I’m honestly thinking about quitting.

title: Would Not Recommend
pros: If you're passionate about customer service and would love to trip over your own feet to make the member happy, then this is the place for you!
cons:
Costco claims to "Take care of our employees" in the code of ethics, but the longer I've been at Costco, the closer I get to the management the more it has come up as a lie. 
During snowpocolypse, Costco started to punish employees who couldn't make it to work and didn't have the PTO to cover it. They later reversed the decision for hourly employed, but salary employees were still not allowed to use sick time for weather excuses.
When COVID started to become a concern, many employees asked for accommodations to work from home.  At first Costco refuses because they felt it was unfair to those working in the warehouses. Then people started to get sick, so they started to let people who had health concerns work from home. Then someone died and Costco got slammed in the news. Well, once members were upset Costco started sending people home. 
Now Costco is requiring people back into the office - even teams that are working successfully from home and maintaining productivity. They won't allow LOA, wwon't consider health concerns. When you ask someone in management with other people around the answer is "We will take it on a case by case basis." When you ask them 1-1, the answer changes to "Quit, demote, or go to the office."
I joined Costco because of their reputation, but their unwillingness to adapt is destroying that reputation and it's apparent its a repeating issue. 
Hiring internally is also really only possible for certain positions, other positions still require experience or applicable degree like most other companies FYI.

title: Amazing benefits!
pros:
- Best insurance I have had in my life
- Wonderful coworkers
- Free food
- Free membership
- Opportunity for growth and upward movement
cons:
- Strange work schedule that is following the retail hours of the store
- Corporate rules
- Managers work 6 days a week during busy season

title: Good company, good people, no accomodations
pros: Costco is a good company to work for. A lot of good benefits for it's members, offers a livable wage. Fellow employees are very welcoming and willing to help you out.
cons: No accomodations depending on your position.

title: Good company-mentally dragging
pros: Awesome benefits, amazing pay and supportive management team. Costco genuinely does take care of its people. I’ve never worked for a company that supported its people in their personal life’s more then Costco does.
cons: Working for Costco, especially in the supervisor/management world you will never have evenings and weekends off. My manager has been with the company 25 years and he closes the front end every single day and has two week days off. This is a member based company so we bend over backwards for our members and get genuinely walked all over us as employees. The words I’m going to go to corporate or I’ve been a an executive member for 10+ years and I send a ton of money at your store, go along way and we have to find a way to say yes. Yes I understand that’s how customer service works but unfortunately when you have a member screaming in your face because they forgot their ID and want to buy liquor and as a corporate company we are required to ask for ID if you appear under the age of 35 and your manager tells you to just go ahead and do it to get the guy out out here...that’s not okay, that’s illegal and makes me look stupid for refusing you service just to end up ringing him up anyway. That’s a small minimal sintuation I can name 100+ situations. You had to have to serious backbone to work for this company. Management has very high expectations as for as performance. We are compensated very well for these expectations however it’s still very mentally dragging.

title: Best place I worked so far
pros: Generous wages and benefits, culture generally tries to do the right thing
cons: Seniority is heavily emphasized which creates attitudes towards work that are counterproductive to what mentality you must have coming in. Expected to do a lot with a little. Constant miscommunications.

title: Great company to work for while studying

cons: No cons that could be mentioned

title: Good job to start, but eventually get out of there.
pros: Excellent pay and benefits. The company takes care of its employees there is no doubt about it.
cons:
The only way to move to up into a good position is if you are married to a manager, dating one, or just straight forward agreeing with everything the higher-level manager says (even if they are wrong)! 

Management has their favorites who they make unique accommodations for. They also give positions to recent graduates (that's what they will tell people when denying them) over a person who has been dedicated to the company for years, even though Costco says no degree is required to move up. 

Another thing, because "employees get paid well, they should be able to do the work of 2 or 3 people" (those were the actual words of a manager). The employees are overworked and stressed out. Many people think employees stay there because they are very content with how they are treated and compensated. Although the pay and benefits are great, most remain there because they have a family to support, no education or have been there too long to start again; therefore, they tolerate the job and try and make it through their shifts.

Most employees have been working there for years; it becomes like a family environment, which is good. However, management is very unprofessional, do not respect people, tell other people's business and they let their "buddies" get away with everything. 

Too many hard working employees (long-time employees) have left because of the managers' inability to follow the guidelines and procedures and their unprofessionalism.

title: A good foundation to build upon
pros:
Everyone starts at $15 an hour, regardless of role in warehouse - with raises based on hours work outlined in the employee handbook. 

Time and a half pay for hours worked on Sundays (excluding Holidays/Easter)

Warehouse is closed on the following days: New Years Day, Easter, Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas

You are paid for the holiday closures listed above, in addition to a floating paid day for MLK jr.

Affordable and high coverage dental, health, vision benefits starting at $23 total per biweekly paycheck.

Part time employees receive benefits listed above at a slightly lower coverage rate.

Casual dress code: Jeans or shorts, collard shirt, tennis shoes

Up to 40hrs scheduled despite being part-time, with 24 minimum guaranteed.

Paid sick time and paid vacation time.

Depending on your supervisor, you may get a Saturday or Sunday off once in a while without requesting off.
cons:
High pressure to work faster and harder every day, regardless of size of task/project.

Members have high expectations for level of service, meaning they will give you a hard time if you ever utter the words "no" to any request or demand.

Management is not eager to train employees. Training is self sought through advice from other coworkers or on computer - which is difficult to find time to do so on a daily basis with high foot traffic. 

Full-time status is extremely rare and hard to reach due to low turnover - regardless of cross training you wait until you either transfer to a warehouse, someone else transfers out, death/illness, or retirement.

title: Great first job/ long-term potential

cons: Management can be a pain but each warehouse is different.

title: Don't Believe in the Hype
pros: Honestly this work is not what its made out to be. If you work the front end doing super easy work (except with carts) getting full hours this job will be great but if you work any of the hard departments and the HARDEST depart of produce then this job all depends on your team. The pay is okay lots of warehouse jobs willing to pay $15 hours as a base and raises are only hours put in (5-8 years) to be maxed out.
cons: There are alot of cons at Costco at least at the Duluth location. The co-workers in the afternoon and evening shift are filled with despicable, condescending, and immature workers. You're practically in a high school with how much judgement you get and they aren't very high on character either. As for the produce department the training is absolutely horrible at least at the Duluth location. Their training is a sink or swim environment which is why they're are short staffed. It also doesn't help that being short staffed that when you do get a hard working employee that being short staffed you can't train to teach that employee because nobody can teach them. Costco is not a good place to work and their turnover rate at least in the Duluth location is high and why they struggle to have employee stay at the hardest department like produce or any other very rigorous department. None of the co-workers shed any explanation or pragmatic way on working the morning shift at Costco and is why everyone literally everyone in the produce department is over 28+ years old (the youngest being maybe 27). Don't believe in the hype at Costco unless you work a easy department like front end, customer service, HR, or any other easy department. Working at the hardest department you still get paid the base pay as anyone. If you think working produce is the same as working the front end doing no labor work but getting the same pay the produce department will always have a terrible culture, short staffed, and high turnover. Costco might be pay alot but eventually these types of work environments, culture, and pay will get their back turned on by their employees and will kill long-term success and vision. I wouldn't be surprised if Costco ends up getting beat by another competitor in the next 50 years. Also, good luck working at produce when there is so much dead weight and everyone is 50+ years old. Costco is a terrible place to work. It takes you 1-2+ years to get full time and that only if it is available and everything falls in place from your training, hours, and availability. There are so many variables at Costco that benefits are not fully given either. You get part time benefits which is no equivocal to full time.

title: Great place to work
pros: You get a great work out. As a morning stocker, you definitely work your upper body, then when members come in you can get a lower body work out pushing carts. When I started I lost 10 pounds in the first month. I work here only for the benefits. I have health insurance at $131/paycheck for a family of 6. All the other benefits are pretty good too. 401k only matches $500, but that's not bad for this line of work. The wages are good for comparable jobs in unskilled labor. Also compared to other unskilled jobs the rate of raises and amount are very good. The work is fast paced and before you know it your done for the day. I feel that the company is doing a great job protecting/supporting the employee during this Covid-19 crisis.
cons: Would like to have an option of working three or four - 8 hr days for part time, instead of five -5 hr days. You may have to work with some people that are jerks or lazy. Especially if you work in a difficult or hard area, like Freezer/Cooler or Produce. Also if you work in those areas you may not be able to get the help you need to finish on time. If you get a job in Front End, you may not have steady days or hours.

title: Costco membership
pros: Great pay .. great benefits and great insurance plan even for part time employees. They promote within which is nice and it is especially a great job for those without a degree that wants to succeed. Also another benefit  is they are all over the US so you can move to other locations without having to change jobs .
cons: Due to job promotion opportunities and just wanting to change departments there is too much movement at times and it messes up the dynamics of the department once running smoothly . Store managers tend to change stores aprox every 5 years and you could have a great working store and a new manager who is weak  come in and destroy the dynamics of the store promoting fear and division.  Some promotions are favoritisms driven And clicks with managers form creating a stressful environment . I sold memberships inside and outside store and it is a very hard job in which you are not appreciated or compensated with higher pay and cashiers make more money then you do. Returns is also in the dept and you are expected to help but if you are not “ labeled” as a cashier you do not get paid unless you keep track of the hours kn the reg. I was their top sales employee for membership and never was rewarded.
